primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God exposes human sin through His holiness and righteousness, not to destroy, but to create a space where the sinner can be forgiven and recreated through the substitutionary work of Christ.

subject.identificatie: God (specifically in His holiness and as the Crucified Christ)
tekstueel_bewijs: God has shown us a great thing.
God made [Jesus] to be sin who knew no sin.
God is truly able to do away with sin and make a completely new person.

object.identificatie: The justification and recreation of the sinner (The 'Clean Heart')
tekstueel_bewijs: Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit within me.
All these human reasons dissolve when seen in the white light of the righteousness of God.
In the Christian community, we can let ourselves be seen as the sinners we really are.
There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself... Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place.
helper.rol_van_geest: External help/Indwelling power (implied in 'renew a right spirit')

tekstueel_bewijs: We are all perpetually smoothing and rearranging reality to conform to our wishes.
The storm of the wrath of God against sin.
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a lack of manners but a cosmic 'storm' and 'wrath' that requires a divine substitute.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The human response of confession and apology in horizontal relationships.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/The Believer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The sermon uses human examples of confession (O.J. Simpson, South Africa) to illustrate the power of the act, but grounds the possibility of true confession in God's prior grace.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: God's Holiness → Justification/New Heart → The Sinner
actantieel_schema_visualisatie.subject_naar_object: God → Recreation of the Human Spirit

voorbeelden_god_subject: God has shown us a great thing.
God is truly able to do away with sin.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We are all perpetually smoothing and rearranging reality.
We come together to acknowledge that God has a case against us.
We lie to others and ourselves constantly.

voorbeelden: We must come to terms with ourselves.
What they want is the confession.
A desire for forgiveness is such a great thing.
The Psalmist demonstrated that he has learned to see sin as God sees it.
Ash Wednesday focuses directly on the theme of self-knowledge.
God is truly able to do away with sin.
We do not need to live out an exhausting, lifelong charade.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes God's 'Pouvoir' (Power) to justify and the human 'Pouvoir' (Freedom) to stop lying because the sentence is already taken by Christ.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from the false safety of ~S1 (Self-deception) to the terrifying S2 (Judgment), then reveals that Christ occupies S2 so the believer can move to S1 (Grace).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Substitutionary Atonement: Christ takes the 'nakedness' and 'storm' so we can be seen as we are without being destroyed.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High. The 'storm of the wrath of God' is described as a real cosmic force.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon demands confession, it identifies God as the one who enables it by removing the threat of judgment through Christ's substitution.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: It takes maturity, wisdom, and true manliness to offer a handsome apology.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: There is Another who has taken the sentence upon himself.
The knowledge of grace has preceded the confession of sin.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: David and the Psalmist are used as models of 'unflinching' self-knowledge, but their ability to be honest is attributed to their confidence in God's mercy.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: God is the one who grants the Psalmist the 'clean heart' that makes such honesty possible.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from the 'exhausting charade' of self-justification.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Justification by faith alone; the believer is 'simul iustus et peccator'.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon perfectly integrates the human need for confession (Secondary Program) into the divine act of atonement (Primary Program).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus, the Son of God, has voluntarily taken our place, naked in the storm.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit (Right Spirit) is the endowment that allows the sinner to sing of righteousness.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; described as an offense against the 'white light of the righteousness of God'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a masterclass in theocentric narrative. It begins with human actants (O.J. Simpson, etc.) but systematically subordinates them to the Divine Subject.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the current shift toward Pouvoir-faire (God's power).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The transition from 'knowing sin' to 'God's power to recreate' is already strong.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (Christ's death) correctly grounds Ethics (our confession).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon avoids the trap of Ash Wednesday moralism by making God's righteousness the active force that both exposes and covers the sinner.

comparatiele_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis might focus on the effective use of the O.J. Simpson anecdote; Greimas shows that this anecdote is merely a 'helper' to establish the 'Axis of Transmission' for the value of confession.
comparatiele_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would focus on the Hebrew context of Psalm 51; Greimas reveals how the preacher re-assigns the 'Subject' role from the Psalmist to Christ in the final act.
comparatiele_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas highlights the 'Subject-Switch' in the final paragraphs where the 'nakedness' of the sinner is transferred to the 'nakedness' of Christ, a structural move that defines the Gospel.

appendices.notities: The sermon is a classic example of Rutledge's 'Grammar of Grace' where the human 'I' of confession is only possible because of the Divine 'He' of substitution.
